WRITING.TITLE: Does Federal Reserve Sentiment Predict Prices of Macro-Tracking ETFs?
WRITING.TEXT:
I got access to a dataset that tracks bullish/bearish sentiment at the Federal Reserve. I tried to find relationships between Fed sentiment and various macroeconomic-tracking ETFs, like GLD (gold), TLT (long-term treasury bonds), and DIA (Dow Jones).
I found that Fed sentiment correlates strongly with SPY and DIA, but that the causal relationship is unclear because both appear to respond to the same overarching macroeconomic variables. Occasionally Fed sentiment reponds first, and at other times, the ETF responds first. This makes it harder to use Fed sentiment for predictive purposes, i.e. as a signal to trade on, though not at all impossible.
You can view my research project [here](https://www.quantopian.com/posts/does-federal-reserve-sentiment-predict-prices-of-macro-tracking-etfs).

I'll go through all of them and give each a grade. I am assuming we're playing Forgotten Empires.
Aztecs (B+): strong eco, and Atlatl makes for great skirms. The monks are potentially quite powerful, but the lack of knights makes it hard for the Aztecs to counter cavalry civs. I think the Aztecs can potentially be played very effectively in the eternal castle age, it's probably just quite difficult as it requires nonstandard tactics.
Britons (A-): Great archers -- Yeomen in castle age is very powerful (very useful against mangonels). Knights lack bloodlines, but a solid archer backing makes up for that. *Note*: TheViper considers the Britons the 4th-strongest Arabia civ, afaik.
Byzantines (B-): lack of bloodlines and no eco bonuses. The castle age cataphract sucks, and it's hard for them to stand out in any way.
Celts (A-): excellent siege that, when massed, is *extremely* hard to take down in the castle age (as opponents will not have access to long-range siege, like bombard cannons and trebs). Woad raiders are very good as well, enough to make up for the lack of bloodlines. Woads provide an excellent meat-shield for their siege. The woodcut bonus is great too.
Chinese (B+): much of the Chinese power lies in the late game. Though their castle age is nothing to complain about -- they have all the techs and bloodlines for their knights as well.
Franks (C+): their 20% cavalry hp bonus *exactly* replaces bloodlines in the castle age. Otherwise, they have nothing to write home about. Note the lack of eco bonuses and the lack of thumb ring.
Goths (B-): good knights, no camels, bad archers. Lack of walls and eco bonuses is pretty inconvenient in this situation. I can see them coming out on top in some situations due to their knights and Huskarls, but not in all of them. I think their quality would depend greatly on how they're played -- a very skilled player could probably do much better with the Goths than with other civs in this situation, but an unskilled player would find them very difficult to use.
Huns (A): the best.
Inca (F): no useful eco bonuses, no cavalry, slinger is useless, kamayuk can only be made at the castle. [More complaints about the Inca](https://www.reddit.com/r/aoe2/comments/3by9s8/incas_listed_as_a_infantry_civ_but_they_dont_look/csqo9r8)
Indians (C-): absolutely no raiding ability in the castle age due to the lack of knights. Camels are nice, but they're defensive -- the Indians have little to no offensive capability. [More complaints about the Indians](https://www.reddit.com/r/aoe2/comments/3ag9l4/spirit_of_the_law_indians_overview/csceluw)
Italians (B): ok all-around. Their eco bonuses (cheaper age upgrade) give them a little rushing advantage, but aside from that, they have no bonuses that make them stand out in particular.
Japanese (B+): they're not missing anything, though their bonuses aren't particularly valuable.
Koreans (B+): lacking bloodlines, but their team bonus (mangonel minimum range reduced) makes up for it. I'm not sure how turtle ships impact the castle age. Eco bonus is weak, but the war wagon is a comparatively strong castle age unit.
Magyars (A-): very good cavalry thanks to the Magyar Huszar, and they have a good archery range. They don't have a particularly good eco bonus, but the Magyar Huszar is a strong unit in the castle age (if you can spam it from multiple castles) that allows for good army combinations with archers.
Mayans (B+): they've got a great eco and plumes. Unfortunately they don't have El Dorado in the castle age -- and they need the extra-hp EEW for their army composition. In an eternal castle age game, they would have to mass pikes + plumes, which can both be countered by skirms. If the opponent throws in a few knights, they can be a tough spot. Some may think that my grade for the Mayans is harsh, but I'm concerned that they do not have a good army composition for a long castle age.
Mongols (A): great archery range -- their cav archers are very good, as are the Mangudai since they don't have an attack delay. The extra HP on light cavalry also makes a significant difference. Generally, the Mongols have an excellent castle-age army composition.
Persians (A): excellent eco bonus, and they basically have a full castle age tech tree. On top of that, war elephants make a considerable castle-age siege weapon. (Compare a war elephant to a ram...)
Saracens (B+): they have a full archery range/barracks/stable. Their galley bonus is considerable. However, I'm not convinced that the Mameluke stands up in the castle age. They also don't have much of a long-term eco bonus.
Slavs (A-): good knights, cheap siege, and the Boyar is probably the best castle-age unit. On the other hand, their archers are missing thumb ring. Their eco bonuses are pretty decent, too. I'm not sure if their lack of thumb ring merits a B+, but I think they would go for siege + cavalry anyway.
Spanish (A/B): no crossbow means they're bound to knights and conqs, both of which are not hard to counter. In a TG they're an A due to their trade bonus, in a 1v1 I think of them as a B. They get some good bonuses in 1v1, but I'm not sure that their army comp stacks up that well, especially since much of the metagame focuses on archery.
Teutons(B+): Ironclad is a useful technology, giving them much better siege. Their archery range lacks thumb ring, and their eco bonus is helpful but not top-of-the-line. Their stable is okay, in that they have knights with bloodlines, but no light cav, camels, or husbandry. On the other hand, castle-age teutonic knights are not that easy to counter. The Teutons can have a potentially powerful army composition.
Turks (C-): a great stable, but unfortunately the turks really aren't much without gunpowder. You can justify the Turks' lack of trash in the imperial age, but not in the castle age.
Vikings (B): great eco bonus, good archers, and good infantry, but their stable is weak. They are, of course, good on the water, but in an eternal castle age, they have a small shortcoming in that they lack fires (though their navy is still much better than average). Their competitive advantage on the water is strongest in the feudal age.

Here are the reasons why hackers don't do this:
1. There's no incentive. Hacking into a financial database is very difficult. What does the hacker get out of it? They can cross off their student loans? There are easier ways for them to make the equivalent amount of money.
2. Financial databases are much better protected than celebrity twitter accounts. They're not impenetrable, but I'd guess that it's about a thousand times harder to break into a financial database than into the average A-list celebrity's social media profile or e-mail account.
3. Erasing data is *hard*. Backups exist all around the world, many of them in "cold storage" (on hard drives completely disconnected from the internet). Beyond that, even if someone were to erase such a database, the contents could be pieced back together by transaction data from other banks, credit bureaus, etc.
4. Coming out of point 3: there exists a *huge* amount of transaction data regarding your debt. Debt is evaluated for likelihood of it being paid off, packaged into huge lumps of similar types of debt, and sold between major banks. The large-scale formatting and sale of debt (and futures contracts, options, etc. on debt) is a massive and fascinating industry. Debt is an investment that is constantly transferred between owners. For that reason, if you have a student loan, or something like that, it probably doesn't just exist in one database, but dozens, if not far more.

Some people call that the "dilution hypothesis:" that the oceans are so big that they can take just about any form of damage. Pour in some industrial waste? No problem, the oceans are big enough to dilute it to a harmless level. Completely overfish an area? No problem, the oceans are big enough to dilute that damage -- the fish will breed elsewhere. Heat the oceans up? No problem, there'll still be cold spots toward the poles.
Unsurprisingly, this approach is unsustainable in the long run, *especially* when every country on earth follows it. Treating a finite resource as if it's infinite usually doesn't go too well.

To respond to your suggestions:
**Franks**
Honestly, I have no idea how the knight gold cost reduction would play out in practice. Knights remain easily countered by pikes, to which the franks have no real good answer.
Making axemen cost wood instead of gold is over-the-top insane. This would make them very OP -- you probably underestimate how powerful mass axemen are. Hint: they are excellent trash-killers. Mass axemen + knights are a very powerful army. Making the axemen cost no gold would mean *both* mass axes (since Franks already have cheaper castles) and more knights, since the player would have more gold to spare -- that'd probably be strongly overpowered.
**Turks**
Their pre-imp isn't actually that bad. They only have bad trash, and that's not terribly important pre-imp. Their early imp is easily one of the strongest in the game, and making age advancement cost 25% less would allow them to reach their early imp while their opponents are still midway through the castle age. They would be incredibly powerful at that stage in the game, again, to an overpowered extent.
**Goths**
Huskarls in any age would make them the strongest civ in the game by a long shot. They would be able to decisively win games in the feudal age, maybe even in the dark age, without a problem.
Villager creation in barracks would give them the best boom of any civ. Granted, you need a castle first, but it'd still be way over-the-top.
**Koreans**
No friendly fire on onagers would mean that they could spam nothing but onagers (and a few trebs/hussars to take down towers/bombard cannons) and win the game without taking any damage.
No minimum range on onagers would make that unit the most powerful in the game (after the war elephant). This should be an obvious problem, since you can mass/spam onagers quite easily.
**Saracens**
Your proposed bonuses buff the saracen late-game. The saracen late-game is already very strong. (How do you beat a big army made of arbalests, siege onagers, and elite mamelukes? Hint: you don't.) The saracens are quite a weak civ, but they need early-game improvements, not late-game improvements.
**Vikings**
A reasonable suggestion. (Though vikings are not terrible on land due to their eco bonuses.)
**Concluding Remarks**
Look at how AoE developers and people in the community propose balance changes. You'll find that the proposed balance changes are usually very small: fire ships are made 10% faster, two-handed swordsman gets +1 attack, etc. The reason for this is that the game's balance is quite delicate, and even small changes can have a big impact.
If you're thinking about how to buff underpowered civs, I suggest you try to isolate the ways in which the civ is *undeservedly* weak, and then make a small buff to that. Think about how the *small* bonus would impact the entire course of the game. Don't consider bonuses that would result in the civ almost invariably winning the game under certain conditions -- that'd be OP.
A good example to think about is the Mongol hunting bonus. They hunt a little faster, and that's very powerful, because it allows them to advance from the dark age to the feudal age a little bit earlier -- they can spare a few vills if they need to, because they've gathered resources much more quickly. This means that they can bring out their feudal army more quickly (i.e. archer/scout rush) and will put pressure on their opponent, putting their opponent on the defensive and slowly getting a marginal advantage in the course of the feudal age. It just *slightly* twists the odds in their favor.
Another small bonus that's important with the Mongols is that the Mangudai has no attack delay: you can run a mangudai, click on a target, and fire *instantly*. This is rare among ranged units, and it's one of the reasons why Mangudai are so powerful for raiding and in small groups.
Those are the sorts of balancing bonuses you should think about.
